Note:
Oxford, Bodleian Library Ashmole 59 (SC 6943) and London, British Library Harley 2251 wrongly add the Envoy from Chaucer’s ‘Venus’ (4904); Cambridge UK, Cambridge University Library Ii.3.21 is introduced into Chaucer’s translation of Boethius; non-source-specific edition is Anderson (1793)
XAnderson, Robert. The Works of the British Poets, or, Complete Edition of the Poets of Great Britain. 13 vols. Vol. 1. Edinburgh, 1793; London, 1795, 1.578.
Subjects: Fortune; mutability; princes, advice to; advice, to princes; envoys; dialogues
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, ‘Balade of Fortune’ — nine eight-line stanzas and a six-line Envoy

BodArcSelB10.First Lines:
This wredchid wolde is transmutaciounAs welle and wo now pore &
                    now honour…
BodArcSelB10.Last Lines:
…Thy last day is ende of myne intresseIn generall I this rule
                    may not fayle
BodArcSelB10.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             More Odd Texts.
Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 77. London: Trübner, 1886; repr. New York and London:
            Johnson, 1967.

BodAsh59.First Lines:
This wrecched worldes transmutacounAs wele and woo nowe poure and
                    nowe honourWith oute ordre or wyse discressyounGoverned is by
                    ffortunes fals errour…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…Preyeþe þane his beste freonde of his
                    noblesseþat to some better estate he may atteyne
BodAsh59.Note:
Followed by Lenvoy to Chaucer’s ‘Complaint of Venus’
                        (5590).
BodAsh59.Attributed Title:
Here foloweþe nowe a compleynte of þe pleintyff ageinst [ageinst]
                    fortune translated oute of ffrenshe in to Englisshe by þat famous
                    Rethorissyen Geffrey Chaucier (f. 37)
BodAsh59.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

Bod638.First Lines:
This wrechid worldis transmutacionAs wele & wo now pore &
                    now honoure…
Bod638.Last Lines:
…Praieth his best ffrende of his noblesseThat to som bettyr
                    estate he may Atteyne

BodFair16.First Lines:
This wrechched (sic) worldes transmutaciounAs wele and woo
                    now pouerte and now riche honoure…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…Prayeth his beeste frend of his noblesseThat to some beter
                    estate he may atteyne

CULIi321.First Lines:
This wrecched worlde is transmutaciounas wele or wo now poeere
                    & now ho honour…
CULIi321.Last Lines:
…preyeth hys best frend of his noblesseThat to som betere
                    estat he may attayne
CULIi321.Attributed Title:
Causer Balades de vilage sanz peinture (f. 53); le repounce de fortune a
                    pleintif (f. 53v); le Respounce du pleintif contre fortune (f.
                        53v); etc.

CamTCC600.First Lines:
Þis wrechched worldes transmutacyounAs weele and woo nowe
                    poure and nowe honnourWith outen ordir or wyse discresciounGouuerned
                    is by ffortunes hye errour…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…Preyeþe his best freond of his hye noblesseÞat to
                    some beter estate he may atteyne
CamTCC600.Attributed Title:
Hit is sayde þat Graunsomme made þis last balade for venus
                    resembled to my lady of york aunswering þe complaynt of Mars and here
                    filoweþe a balade made by Chaucier of þe louer and of dame ffortune
                    (p. 142); Dialoge bytwene þe lover and fortune (RT)
CamTCC600.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.

             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

BLHar2251.First Lines:
This wrecchid worldis transmutaciounAs weele and woo now poore and
                    now honour…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…Prayeth that his best friend of his noblesThat to som better
                    estate he may atteyne
BLHar2251.Note:
With the envoy of ‘The Complaint of Venus’ (5590) following the
                    usual ‘Envoy’.

            London: Johnson, 1967.

BLLan699.First Lines:
The wrechid werldis transmutacionAs wele & woo now poore &
                    now honour…
BLLan699.Last Lines:
…Thi laste day is eende of my intresseIn general this rewle
                    may nat faile
